{"step_by_step_thinking": "The buccinator muscle is a thin, flat muscle of the cheek that draws the corner of the mouth laterally and allows one to blow air out of the mouth. It is pierced by several structures. The labial branch of the facial nerve, the buccal branch of the mandibular nerve, and the parotid duct all pierce the buccinator. However, the molar mucous glands do not pierce the buccinator, they are located in the buccal mucosa near the molar teeth.", "answer_choice": "D. Molar mucous glands"}
